profileText: A Representative from Connecticut; born in Litchfield, Conn., on December 1, 1805; was graduated from Yale College in 1825; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1827 and began practice in Litchfield; postmaster of Litchfield from January 4, 1832, to January 27, 1842, and from September 2, 1842, to September 28, 1846; member of the State house of representatives in 1851, 1866, and 1874; elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1861-March 3, 1863); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1862 to the Thirty-eighth Congress; continued the practice of law until his death in Litchfield, Conn., November 21, 1885; interment in East Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1820-1880, 8 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain correspondence and legal documents of four generations of family members. Of particular note is ongoing correspondence between brothers, Lewis B. and George C. Woodruff, both trained at Litchfield Law School, George remaining in Litchfield to practice law whereas Lewis began a practice in New York City, eventually becoming a federal judge. Subjects include the political atmosphere in the 1830s, election day events in New York, N.Y., and rural Connecticut, and the conflict between the Federalists and the Democratic Republicans. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Woodruff Family Papers, ca. 1770-1927, 12.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include George C. Woodruff. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.
